reviewText:
Early Access Review

Words cannot describe the amount of enjoyment I've had playing this game and interacting with its – at the time, small community since February. Yes, contradictory to my playtime here on Steam, I've been playing this game since February of this year.

Rivals of Aether is a fast paced, Platform-fighter (Smash Bros. like game). And is the closest to Smash Bros. any game has ever been aside from Smash Bros. itself of course. However the core mechanics have been mixed up a bit.

This is basically a review for you folk that know how Smash Bros. works, maybe have some experience in the competitive scene, and are already hovering over the 'Add to Cart' button. If you don't know what I'm talking about, you might want to read another review. However I can definitely vouch for the game being an incredibly fun experience for the more casual players too.

So, let's get to it.
No Shield, but instead a Parry that on hit puts your enemy in a longer hitlag state, and grants you a short window of invulnerability.

No Ledges, but instead you can wall-jump once out of your Up-Special/Special Fall, and use your Up-Special again.

No L-Cancelling, but instead aerials more or less auto cancel on landing. So the game is still very fast, just requires less inputs to go fast.

No Grabbing, and nothing to replace it. This adds a different dynamic to the game for sure. Whether that's good or bad, is really subjective.

Directional Airdodges are a thing, however they don't put you into Special Fall afterwards. You still only get one Airdodge per air-time, and trust me, you better use that one Airdodge you get very wisely. I will detail why in the next bullet point... And yes there is Wavedashing. Whether it's useful or not is hard to say at the moment, you should just see for yourself.

Hitstun can feel extremely overwhelming when playing against a skilled player. Perfect DI (Yes DI is also a thing) can be crucial to stopping your enemies combos. The Airdodge you get helps, but you only get one per air-time, so again, use it wisely.

1v1 Unranked Online (Invite or vs Random) only at the moment. If you were planning to do doubles online, that might be a thing in the future, just not now.

If you are planning to use your Gamecube controller, and you already own an adapter for your PC, follow this guide and be illuminated - http://bigfriendlygames.net/2015/09/19/rivals-of-aether-on-steam/ Though I must say that Xbox and Playstation controllers work perfectly for this game.

Amount of Characters will be 8 at full release (This is early access). However the future might be holding some DLC for us, who knows? As of writing this, 7 characters are playable and they are all excessively unique from each other.
I will probably revise this review from time to time, but for now this should be pretty much everything you could want to know.

I hope to see you in-game!

Also a big thanks to everyone involved in the early days of the game. It's gonna go far. I'm sure.

Edit: It's been a while since I wrote this, but all of it still applies, and things have only gotten better!

Cons:-Not alot of characters, yet

I give this game a 9/10 wombo combos

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals of Aether is the smash bros nintendo wont give us.
The trailers truly do not do the pace of this game justice. It is way quicker and more combo intense than even both trailers let on.

It is an incredible combination of Melee movement and Smash 64 hitstun. This comes together in the form of incredible combos that can sometimes be 0 to death if you read peoples techs and DI properly.

YES! THERE IS DI. Combo DI and Smash DI. There is wavedashing, wavelanding, edge cancelling, reverse aerial rush, some characters can jump cancel, theres a character with a double jump cancel and the 8th character can DACUS. Ignore the negative reviews. The lack of shielding makes this an incredibly strategic and aggressive game and the latest patch really made camping difficult and the balance of the game has never been better! The negative reviewers need to GET GOOD. Learn to parry god dammit!

There is no ledge, every character has a wallkick that refreshes your recovery and the recoveries in rivals are insane so edge guarding is incredibly fun. There are no items. The stages are all playable and there are no banned" stages. Hazards can be put on for fun but they are always disabled in online play and in fact ive never seen them used.

This game is a love letter to competetive smash fans and i am incredibly passionate about it and would hate to see people turned away by comments like "i cant parry good enough games imba!!111"

If you love smash
date: just buy it right now. Quit wasting time! And if your a fighting game fan in general
recommended:
theres definetly the depth of gameplay youll need to find something here.

Let this game reach its full potential. <3

"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is heavily inspired by Super Smash Brothers Melee. If you enjoy Melee, or Smash in general, you will most likely enjoy this game. Rivals of Aether takes many idea from Melee and implements them into their own game. The special thing to the game is the characters. Each character is super unique and very different. Every character has a very distinct moveset that is different from what Melee could ever achieve. There are also new mechanics to the game, and some mechanics taken away from Smash. One example is the Parry system. Sheilding in Smash has been replaced with a parry in Rivals of Aether. There are, however, techniques from melee that carry over, such as wavedashing.

Bottom line is, if you like Smash, you will probably enjoy Rivals of Aether. I personally think this game is definitely worth the buy and overall an amazing game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To everyone saying that the game is unbalanced, or that the stages are stupid, are legit just bad or using keyboard controls. Providing your willing to put in some time, you will end up absolutely loving this game, most people get addicted (average playtime I see is like 80 hours) very quickly. Me personally, well I'm way beyond 80 hours. Don't be discouraged by super good players online, odds are they've just put more time into this game than you. Now that that's cleared up, here are the pro's and con's.
Pros	-Well-Balanced
-Incredibly Fast
-Mechanic's are almost perfect
-Every character is completely different
-Literally no skill cap, you can always get better under all circumstance
-Competitive fighter that has a secondary party game function (think smash bros)
-Graphics are very appealing
-Combo's are incredibly fun
-Great community
-Online tournaments, every first sunday of the month theirs a monthly with a 120$ prize pool distributed between the top 8

Cons	-Unfished-ish, some bugs and slightly stupid things
-Hard to get good at, 200 hours and not even amazing yet :P
-Klling opponents can get very difficult with certain characters
-Edgegaurding is incredibly difficult

Overall 10/10, fantastic game and it's not even finished yet, get it under any circumstance.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At last a great platform fighter (i.e. Smash clone) on PC. I’m somewhere between beginner and intermediate, so I can’t comment on how the game is played at high level. I’ll share my experience and thoughts as a casual player.

The controls have an elegant simplicity that grants the game its appeal and low skill floor. Simply input a direction and one of the attack buttons simultaneously to perform an attack in that direction. There are three attack buttons corresponding to tilts, strong attacks and special attacks. The same controls apply universally to all characters and they all share quite similar tilts and strong attacks, so that once you learned to play with one character, you can find your bearings with any of them.

There are only 8 characters but each has a pretty unique moveset with some specific quirks, especially when it comes to special attacks. This can be both great and somehow bothering at the same time. Great because every character has a distinct playstyle and everyone is guaranteed to find at least a few tailored to them among this small but varied cast. Bothering because it steepens the learning curve for two reasons when compared to Smash. First, it slightly gets in the way of skill transfer from character to character. Secondly, matchups knowledge becomes more important.

By no means I want to give the impression that this is an actual issue and that the game is in fact hard to learn, it is still very easy to pick up, it only makes it harder to master. And yet, RoA brings some of its own simplicity to the genre. It pares down the mechanics and trims the formula to its essential components by removing grabs, edge grabbing, L-cancelling, shields (replaced with parries), … What remains at the core is a streamlined gameplay that prominently features exhilarating kickass combos.

The result is a mechanically tight game with a low skill floor, high skill ceiling, and a learning curve sloped to quickly and comfortably project players towards the more fast paced, technical and competitive side of platform fighters.

I absolutely recommend this game to anyone who prefers Melee to other Smash games. This is the closest you will get on PC. It manages to capture both the simplicity and depth that I enjoyed in Melee while still having its own flavor and charm.

Although it isn’t a party game and is definitely positioned towards the competitive end of the spectrum, I also strongly recommend it to newcomers. I mostly play casually with friends at my skill level, and even so I enjoy it much more than the few other alternatives on PC. The action is fast paced, the combos you can pull off even as a beginner are really awesome, and it’s overall extremely fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: DI = directional influence. When you get hit, you can hold a direction on your control stick and you'll alter your trajectory from the hit.

I was part of the alpha test from August 31 2014, and the most recent test build I was apart of was March 2015.

I instantly fell in love and started showing the game off and playing with my friends. All of us play melee competitively, and while there are some differences from Smash, this game could easily pass as part of the main series.

Cirby (on steam), is a member of the community I respect very, very much. He wrote an excellent review for this game, and I suggest you read it. His review will explain the major differences between RoA and a Smash game.

I'm going to talk about how /fun/ this game is.

If you look back at all of the best video games in history 99/100 times they all have one thing in common: a quality movement system. To explain what I'm talking about lets look at Mario Kart. Normally you have total control over your kart, you can speed up, speed down, break, hop, do a trick, angle yourself, etc. The only time you don't have control is when you get hit by an item. The frustrating part about getting hit with an item isn't that you stop, the frustrating part is that you lose ALL control. You can't try and steer to avoid falling off of the track, you just go forward a little at a fixed speed.

Pack in a great hitstun/combo system, some decent players that can read, react and play mind games, a GREAT 1v1 online system and 4 player offline for those into that kind of thing and you have a great overall package.


Here are some gfycats of some real gameplay (from an older build, but still the same game really) so you can see some..not randy day 1 gameplay. Keep in mind, these are from an older build and are not fully the same as the product you are buying now.


https://gfycat.com/HeftyIncompleteArgentineruddyduck

https://gfycat.com/WindyHilariousHochstettersfrog

https://gfycat.com/IlliterateFaroffFawn

https://gfycat.com/SizzlingZestyKiwi

https://gfycat.com/GiantSpryDassierat


Notice how much fun we're having? While these are highlights, cool, fun, unique stuff like this happens ALL. THE. TIME.


Now, go read Cirbys review if you haven't already, and if you have any questions please feel free to ask.

http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198040702301/recommended/383980/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game... oh my god, where to begin?

Rivals of Aether is an Indie platformer fighting game, much to the likes of Nintendo's Super Smash Brothers series, however, even tho they share the platformer fighting genre, this game knows how to make itself stand out.

VISUALS
The art style of this game is charming, mostly based around pixel art sprites and the likes, the characters are pretty memorable in their visual aspect, and their design has a certain tone of personality to it that makes it feel pretty unique. It's not graphically intensive or anything so you will most likely be able to run it in a medium-low end computer.

SOUND
While the music is alright, not something extremely memorable, i have to give Kudos to the ones behind the sound design, it's, in a few words, on point, every attack and hit sounds how it should and it really makes it feel like more of an impact when you land it.

COMBAT AND GAMEPLAY
The meat of Rivals of Aether is it's combat system, while obviously inspired in SSB, it differs quite a bit, there's no ledge grab system, you get your moves, a walljum and an air dodge, use them how you want, you also have acces to a pretty unique(even tho a bit small) roster, with each character having it's own gimmick, you have Wrastor's incredibli strong air game coupled with the ability to triple jump, or maypuls marking, allowing you for easy saves(Try to avoid using it for saves against higer skilled players) or double tapping your strong attacks, so you'll have a hard time adjusting if you are like most of the playerbase, who come from SSB.

My only real complaints to this game are the fact that, first, it isn't really begginner friendly, with a stupidly high skill ceiling, coupled with a matchmaking that's only a system that pairs you with the first other opponent it finds and a community that came from a similar game of which a lot of people already know what they're doing makes it really tough for begginners who don't have much experience in the platformer fighting genre, and second, There is no 4 player online matches at the date of this review.

To sum it up:
PROS
Memorable character design
Great fighting system
Good sound design
High skill ceiling, meaning there's a lot of gameplay available
E-sports presence

CONS
No actual matchmaking
Not begginner friendly
Only 1v1 multiplayer available
Story hasn't been implemented

TL;DR:
I'd recommend you to buy this game if you're willing to spend the time on a competitive game to develop your skills in it, if not, i'd wait for the game to be fully released out of early access to give it a look.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I went into this game expecting a fun, smash bros-like game and I can say it's far exceeding my expectations. ROA has great pixel art, with each character and stage looking vibrant. ROA has an interesting selection of 6 characters (2 additional characters planned in future updates), from a four-legged orca whale to a styling avian. Each character is completely unique, my favorite being Forsburn, a dagger-wielding assassin type character with abilities such as
- smokescreen (neutral special) to deliver a surprise attack from an unknown position.
- decoy (side special) to throw off the opponent, with the same abilities as its source, its attacks can also create/extend combos.
Another thing I like about Aether is the crazy amount of moves that combo into each other, it's all so smooth, and the game is only in alpha so there's no doubt it'll even further improve.
My one complaint so far is the online matchmaking. About 90% of my matches have been players immediately self-destructing without even attempting to fight. Though this may be due to lag on the other end, it's not apparent to me as each of the games have been smooth on my end. it's. really. annoying. It takes forever to get into a match where the person actually plays. I feel like some sort of penalty could possibly be implemented to fix this.
If you're looking for an interesting fighting game with endearing art, music, characters, and smooth gameplay, you're in the right place! I can't wait to try it out with friends. This game no doubt makes a great couch co-op game to waste time with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros
-Perfect online code for an indie game.
-Very nice and memorable 16 bit music
-A very cool and very diverse roster to relate yourself with and all of them share a few moveset seen in smash bros.
-Not a smash bros clone; it's a different game, different feel... As in dota 2 is not like Lol.
-I coudln't tell if this game was in Early Access, i only found out after a long session of gameplay.

Cons
-Controls are not exactly like it is in smash bros so you must get used to the changes.
-No ranking as of yet; be prepared to lose again and again...

Style:

This game reminds me of Megaman more than Smash bros because of the sound effects.

When you die, same sound effect as when you die in a megaman game. Each stages looks like a bit of what you usually see in a megaman game.
With that said, you will have the impression that each enemies come from a megaman game(the bosses). I know, i sound like a broken record by now, but if you play it yourself, you will eventually get it.

Gameplay and differences from Smash bros:

-Blocking has been removed and replaced with a parry. On parry, your opponent become unable to move for a split second which leaves you enough time to counter-attack.
-You can no longer use grapples and theres no grapple-type character.
-For the melee freaks, you can wave-dash and it's a lot more easier to perform.
-You can perform Air-dodge only once while in mid-air. Afterwards, you can do anything else while still in mid-air.
-After Up+special(Up+B smash bros), you can only do it again if you bounce off the wall and you can no longer edge-guard.
-Extremely reliant on juggles-combos.

ROA vs SB:

More like melee, but you don't feel like you must exploit the game to win and while everything is easy to perform (including wave-dashes), high level play is still a very long way after you feel confident enough.

I personally find this game to be a lot more addictive than any other smash bros game; even the online net-code is better than the one found in smash 4.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is addicting. For the price, it's well worth your money whether you're looking to play Smash but don't have a Nintendo console or are already really into Smash. There's a lot this game offers. The character roster may look small, yes. Right now it has a mere 6 fighters with 2 more to be released by the game's launch, and only 5 stages with 3 more to be released, but the depth the gameplay brings to the table is so engaging that I find it hard for me to not look forward to coming back to it again and again.

The fighters take a lot from multiple Smash characters and mix them into one but a lot of their movesets and specials are so unorthodox from Smash that it's a breath of fresh air for avid fans like myself. The major differences you'll notice right away are that there is no ledge grabbing and there is no shielding. You can wall jump (usually) after doing your up special and you can parry attacks (hitting the block button exactly when the other person's move would hit you). It leaves them vulnerable for a second for you to counter-attack. It fits with the game's playstyle and it's really cool to see new takes on standard Smash mechanics.

Wavedashing is also here, and it's much easier to do than in any of the Smash games. No character has a short wavedash, so it's viable for everybody and useful to learn and apply to your fighting eventually. Overall I'd rate this game a 9.5/10, would be a perfect score but for real can we please nerf Zetterburn and Kragg a bit? Thanks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals of Aether is a fantastic game that balances the best elements of similar games like Super Smash Bros.

Pros:
-It retains some of the technical skill involved in Melee and Project M (i.e. wave-dashing) but does not overwhelm you with constant skills like L-Cancelling or SHFFLing. I have personally found L-Cancelling to be a hassle, so I was happy to find that there is very little (maybe even zero) landing lag in Rivals of Aether.
- The basic attacks are all there, but a lot of characters have much more interesting mechanics (i.e. Wrastor's aerials freezes him in the air.) Combo-ing with these attacks feels awesome due to the small amount of hitlag on each attack.
-There are no more grabs or ledge grabbing which some people find questionable. However, the lack of grabs adds to much more fluid gameplay relying on attacks to start combos rather than grabs. Also, ledge grabbing has been pratically replaced with wall jumping, which is much different to say the least.
-In my opinion, the characters in this game are much more unique than the characters featured in Super Smash Bros. Each character in this game has a unique gimick besides just attacks, specials, and aerials. I hope that future characters will flow as well as the current ones.
-Rivals of Aether is a game that endorses competetive play and is built for it. This game will feel like a Smash Bros. game made for competetive play. If you like Smash Bros. You will like this game.
-Has support for Xbox 360 controllers and keyboard. You can also use a Gamecube controller if you follow these instructions: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yVu8xJ7Bs6o
-The music is very good, and I personally love the art style. However, due to the lack of stages the music can become   repetetive.
-Comes with a cool training mode that allows you to experiment and play with bots in any way you want.

Cons:
-Many of the fights experienced online will be choppy and filled with button lag. From my experience, most games I've played have been realtively low on the lag scale. Whenever I play with friends there is no noticeable input lag or choppiness in the gameplay.
-The game is in early access, so you don't really know whether this game will really become something with your money. I say this from personal experience with many early-access games that I have purchased, which I'm aware is my own mistake.
-I don't necessarily know if this is a con, but to all the Melee fans out there: Rivals of Aether is not Melee 2.0.

Conclusion:
I definitely missed lots of pros and cons, but overall, I believe Rivals of Aether is very entertaining and worth the price tag due to the replayability of the game. As stated previously: If you like Super Smash Bros. in any way, shape, or form, you will like this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals of Aether is a Smash-inspired fighting game (or 'Platform Fighter' as some people call this subgenre). It carrys over many mechanics from Super Smash Bros. Melee, praised as one of the best competetive games ever made, mimicing it's fast and combo-heavy game pace with a quality unmatched, while also staying original and accessible.

This game instantly feels familiar to anyone that played Super Smash Bros. before, but can also be enjoyable for people unfamiliar with this genre. It offers the simplicity to be picked up almost immediately by gamers of every skill level, while also offering advanced techniques and mechanics, creating a deep and competetive atmosphere with a seemingly endless skill ceiling. If you strive to be the best or just want some casual games with a friend, you will definitely find like minded people in this wonderful community, who can help you get better or can have a good laugh with you.

I highly recommend you to just give this game a try. Its a beautiful gaming experience that is just as much competetive, as it is accessible, surrounded by a great community that wants to push this game further and have fun doing so.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is better than smash bros from a competitive standpoint. It's quite similar, but it's better;

1. It's $15 as opposed to the hundreds of dollars for a Wii U and Smash Bros (you still have to spend money on a gamecube adapter and controller if you use those, but you can use any USB controller or keyboard if you prefer.

2. Made by a company that wanted to make a more competitive version of smash. They succeeded by making a platform fighter that has an incredibly balanced (albeit small) roster, no items, neutral stages, and advanced techniques reminiscent of Super Smash Brothers Melee to create a high skill ceiling.

3. The simple graphics allow almost any computer to run this game at 60 fps with no problems whatsoever.

4. The online matches don't feel as laggy as the online mode in Smash Bros for Wii U.

5. The characters aren't limited to pre-existing games/universes like they are in Smash Bros. The characters in RoA are original and actually feel like they were designed to beat each other to a pulp, unlike some Smash Bros characters *cough*wiifittrainer*cough*.

6. It has much better practice mode features, such showing hitboxes and knockback direction as well as being able to advance frame by frame.

7. There is no tripping, rage, or stale moves. This removal of variables makes combos go off much more consistently and intuitively.

This game is just really, REALLY good. If you like Smash or any fighting games, it is DEFINITELY worth the $15.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals of Aether is a game clearly inspired by the Super Smash Bros. series, but with it's own innovation on the formula. The core idea is the same: Deal as much damage as possible to your opponent as possible, while taking the least you can. Higher damage means you get sent farther when hit, ultimately resulting in players being sent flying off stage, either colliding with the end of the screen and dying, or being forced to try and make their way back to the stage with their opponent actively trying to prevent it.

If you're looking for a fun fighting game featuring some stellar game design, you've come to the right place.

If you are a fan of Smash, you absolutely need to play this game. The unique mechanics it brings to the table make it familiar but also a breath of fresh air.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like smash bros, you will like this. it's pretty much the same game with fresh new characters and ideas. It take skill, but I would probably say less than smash, but that is just due to the amount of time that people have been playing it and had experiance with it. Also, the inputs are easier compared to melee, for instance. This game is like somehwere in between PM/melee and brawl/smash 4 and the devs have nearly hit the sweetspot.  this game is fairly balanced, though I do have a few things to pick on and say to the contrary.

(EDIT: below I complain about forsburn. He is not the easies to play but he is very strong, I have come to realize. He is a top tier character and this game is very well balanced for the most part.. people used to think fors and maypul were bad but it turns out they are the best in the game. All the other characters are still competitive, though. The opinions below were premature and do not reflect the current meta, but a much earlier one; they also reflect how I felt as a less skilled player. If you like fast paced platform fighting and competitive play get this game. the cast is small but that is for balance reasons. THe cast is very diverse while small, and this game has given me some of the best experiences of any I've ever played. The community is very good for the most part. I have literally added 80 to my friendslist through this game)

This game is great but it defnitely needs a few tweeks. I play forsburn, probably one of if not the hardest characters in the game, and while I am happy with him, it is hard not to fall prey to  the rest of the cast, particularly wrastor and zetterburn.
Heck he has a hard time agains most everybody. Once you get to learn how to play him, things do get easier and more doable, but it's not hard for things to become and uphill battle if your opponent know what they are doing as well. I think he requires a bit more awareness and reads, which is not bad i guess, but it is also true of bowser, the worst char in melee.

So I think forsburn may be a bit underpowered, but that may just speak to the difficulty of playing him. its not that his moves are super bad, they are just easier to punish than most other characters.

The rest of the cast seems really tight. wrastor is ridiculous but they just nerfed him so.....  not gonna go any further than that. Not that the rest of the cast isnt great. wrastor can just wall you out, his moves have a ton of priority and range, and he can through out tons of them.

anyway, this game is a lot of fun and i played 16 hours in 2 days.. it's a bit addictive.... props to the devs hope to see more great things.

The TRUE review (early acces 0.02):

I could just say: hands down best smash game ever 10/10 would 10/10 again;

This game is truly amazing, if you were good at smash, then you will get pro in less than a week, if you have played any fighting game, than it's the same thing, but with platforms.
PROS:
+A refreshing experience to a Smash Bros game type
+Easy to master
+No toxicity in this game (aka: no chat)
+Cheap
+Nostalgic
+Incredibly satisfying to win
+Brings incredible moments, with insane combos
+A game that WILL evolve, because developers will keep on updating (more people buy, more updates and cool content)
-It's F%$#ing amazing

CONS:
-Little ammount of content (not sure how fast content wil be released) still in early access
-Can get repetitive if the content doesn't flow (but that doesn't stop me and many others for playing it 900 hours)
-ONLINE will be extremely laggy 50% of the time (you better just jump off the ledge until you find an opponent near your area)
-Has some weird bugs and glitches
-Needs a bigger developing team
-You can't choose special brawls or interesting rules to spice things up with friends
-Some features are still blocked (like online free-for-all, or more like, lag-for-all)
-You need to play this with controller, it feels to clunky with the keyboard
-This game will steal so much time of your life ;_; but I love it :D

Take in mind that this is an Early access game, so many of the cons (if not all) could get fixed.
We just have to wait and see what the devs have in mind to make this game unique and Popular (Popular=More buyers=More money=More content=More fun= :D)
So try to spread the word of the AETHER and bring your friends.
This might not yet be the game we dreamed of, but it can be.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHonestly amazing from what I have seen so far. This game stays true to its goal of bringing smash to pc, not only does it have the feel of melee but it isnt just a clone unlike all the other browser based smash games. The characters are honestly my favorite part about it, every single one feels 100% viable from a competetive aspect. Even Kragg, who fills the role of the slow paced big character, which usually is out of place in the smash games, feels great and playable against the rest of the cast. All of the cast feels vibrant and different from the rest which is amazing to see. For example my favorite (orcane) has entire strings that are possible off of a bubble detonation from a puddle. In a competetive fighting game, diversity is a GREAT thing to see, as it keeps the game fresh. It gets tiring to see the same characters all the time. From my short time playing it I can already see this game has immense potential in both a competetive sense and just for casual fun with friends. I would definetly reccomend this to anyone who is a fan of the smash franchise or just fun in general.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is what an amazing alternative to the Smash bros-esque gameplay that we all know and love. Its suprisingly well balanced for just having hit early access and brings some new fun mechanics to the table while removing things such as grabs and shields, opting for a perry system to maintain a faster pace in gameplay. The developer seems to have a realistic plan that he's serious about completing involving more exciting content that will add to both the multiplayer and single player experience. The game right now has some of the best netplay ive ever seen in a fighting game and even though right now there is only 1v1 matchmaking the developer has confirmed that they are working on having more players in lobbys.

Already its a great game and i believe it will be even better in the future, its definitely worth 15$ and hours of your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

All time favorite game. It has an amazing and supportive community, fairly good online tourney scene, and it just feels great to play. Imagine melee, but where all the advanced tech is intentional, so it feels so much smoother. I can't recommend this game to competitive players enough. Do make sure you have a controller though.

The biggest issue right now; however, is the relatively high learning curve for new players or people unexperienced in platform fighters and a lack of tutorials to counterract this. This can lead to a lot of hate or salt. The thing is, the RoA community majorly counterbalances this, if you need help, you can literally just ask someone like me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing controls and solid mechanics, it just feels good to play. Every attack (save for Wrastor's air smash attacks) all cancel on the ground - so it's like the game has built in L cancelling which makes comboing and stringing super fluid and fun to do.

Even though the cast seems small, each character is so unique and fits its own little niche so perfectly you feel like a larger cast would dilute the game's charm.

The awesome pixel artstyle feel very nostalgic and fits really well thematically.

The music is great - each level feels like it was inspired from a certain series (The air stage sounds Megaman inspired, the Castle/Temple stage feel Link To The Past inspired etc) and you can't help but jam along - you also get the stage music for free! (it's in the files!)

Stages are all different thematically and each include different platform layouts for diversity.

10/10, one of the best fighters I've ever played. It's like they took everything that makes Melee great, made it that little bit more accessible and less-hard to play to widen their market.

Nerf Kragg tho.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a huge Super Smash Bros fan, then you will love this game. Rivals of Aether is a Smash Bros based game that has melee techs. If you really like Super Smash Bros Melee, then you should certaintly get this game. If you like Melee but you don't have the opportunity to play it, then this is a pretty good alternative. The roster is small and is kinda made up of Furries, but I say that's a bonus since it makes the characters more unique. I don't want to spoil anything but....there is a character that is a mix of Marth and Ice Climbers.
As of right now there is 1 character left to be released, but the Devs won't disappoint because all the Characters are really fun. And the best thing is, you won't have to pay for the new character. The game has a decent amount of stages but only a quarter of them are available at the moment (I'm guessing some of them are still in development or something). If you like Smash you should really get this game. If you don't have a Smash compatible console and you're interested in Smash, you should get this too, as it is very similar to the very fast paced fighting game Super Smash Bros Melee but with a twist.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This isn't just Smash Bros. on Steam, it's a genuinely clever take on the formula. Some of the core mechanics are different, like parries instead of shields and grabs, but it's still going to feel pretty familiar if you've played Smash before. What really sets it apart and makes it feel unique is each individual character's design.

There aren't many characters (6 so far, 2 more on the way), but each one has some kind of mechanic in the form of something they can place somewhere on the stage. Orcane can place a puddle on the ground that he can teleport to or detonate into a pillar of bubbles; Maypul can create a plant that can snare enemies or redirect her projectile; Wrastor can create a horizontal jetstream that he moves faster in, etc. Each character is extremely unique, and it makes the small roster feel a lot bigger than it is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR: Very good game that is Smash Bros, but isn't Smash Bros. Easy to pick up and fun to play.
This is a very solid game with solid gameplay to boot. While this game is a Smash-esque game, it has a totally different feel. Just as a warning: Do NOT come into this game thinking it's Melee or something. It's not. Refrain from making your layout the exact same as Smash. It might not help.So, first up are the characters: All 6 of the characters (Soon to be 7) are very unique, and while some have similarities to other characters in Smash i.e. Zetterburn is like  Fox and Wolf mixed into one, there are charcters like Kragg who are nothing like other characters in Smash. Everything in this game auto cancelling, meaning that you can preform combos upon combos and they're pretty simple to preform. The online is really good. I never have to wait to long to get a match, and even when I do, I have very little lag. But when there is lag it's ungodly bad. The other thing I feel that I should mention is that the AI is dumb. I don't really bother playing against the AI and stick to Online matches. As of current the single player experience is poor. Get it for online. Finally, I will note the differences. There is not shield, and there is no ledge to grab. Wall jumping can seem a tad alien at first, but it will start to feel more natural as you play more. You also only get one air dodge, so use it wisely.
To conclude, this is an amazing game for a good price. I highly recommend it, especially if your a fan of Smash, or if you just want to play a more unique kind of fighting game. Playing this game with friends is also especially fun, but you can only do 1v1 as of current. Have fun and see you in game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wrote a review on it before saying that the world doesn't need an SSB clone.

Well, I spent more time on it, and it's a charming little game actually.  The music is nice, the stages aren't too bad, and the characters all have their gimmicks.  I can also use my gamecube controll with it.  Also, there's no shield in this game, instead there's a counter(?) mechanic, where if you're hit while dodging (there's a button for it, not just running around), your opponent won't be able to attack and you'll get a free initiate on them within 2 seconds or so.  You can roll, but it's easily punishable.

Right now, there's an abundance of Zetterburns and Kragg(?) players online.  I run into more of them that do the same thing, but that's okay, because they're easy characters to combo with.

Brief overview of the characters.

I'll begin with Orcane, and he's the one I play most.  This guy is a killer whale (orca) with legs.  Why does he need legs?  For kicking ♥♥♥.  His special mechanic is a drop of sludge he can fire and place anywhere on the stage, and also acts as a projectile to disrupt your enemy's recovery, or to provide recovery options via is up-special, or a trap (down-special, and forward-air) that can screw your enemy's approach (This is how you ruin the advance of Zetterburn and Wrastor players since they open with projectiles and dash after it hits).

Next is Zetterburn, if you couldn't guess it, he's all about the fire.  I haven't played him, but there's a lot of them out there.  He's pretty deadly if you let him fight completely on his terms.  He also relies on a DoT mechanic by lighting parts of the stage on fire, and if you are hit by the attacks that do that, or walk into the fire you'll begin to take damage.

Here's Wrastor.  Remember Captain Falcon and Falco from Super Smash Bros?  Well, they got gay and decided to have a love child.  He's a bird with aviator goggles.  His special mechanic is that you launch a tornado, and it leaves a line where your movement is faster in that line after the tornado.  He also accels in air combat, and his strong attacks (think Smash Attack) all require you to be in the air to use.  He also doesn't double jump, he flaps his wings and pentuple jumps.

How about Maypul?  This is Rocket Raccoon's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off brother who runs around cutting people with leaves and seeds and ♥♥♥♥.  His brother got to go to space and become friends with a living tree named Groot, while this guy got stuck using his tree pals as weapons.  His mechanic is obviously the trees, you throw seeds onto your enemy, and bait them into your down-special and it wraps them up.  His smash attacks have long distance but not a wide hitbox.  He recovers by holding his up-special to use a vine to jump back up on stage near his enemy.  His down-air (or dair) also spawns a root from the floor of the stage, allowing it to hit anyone on the stage regardless of how far away he is from the ground.

KRAGG!  IF THERE WAS  FIGHTER THAT WOULD YELLING ALL THE TIME AND SOUND OBNOXIOUS, IT BE KRAGG.  HE'S LIKE HERACROSS FROM POKEMON, EXCEPT HE YELLS (not really, but every game has one).  HIS MECHANIC IS HURLING ROCKS AND STUFF AT HIS ENEMIES.  HE THROWS ROCK, ROCK HITS ENEMY, ROCK LANDS ON STAGE.  KRAGG GET ANGRY, HIT ROCK, SHATTERS AND FLIES IN THE DIRECTION IT WAS HIT, GOING ALL OVER ENEMY LIKE A TEENAGER IN A TUBESOCK.  KRAGG FLY OFF STAGE, NO PROBLEM FOR KRAGG.  KRAGG SUMMON ROCK PILLAR ANYWHERE ON THE STAGE.  ALSO GOOD INITIATOR.

Lastly, for right now, is Forsburn.  He's a fox who cosplays V for Vendetta.  He has a stealth mechanic, haven't played him much.  He wields a knife and can spawn a doppelganger to confuse your opponent, and can also summon smoke to disappear into, or inhale to become the harbinger of lung cancer (not entirely sure, but I think this is what enables him to make his clone).

Be wary, it is in early access with known bugs, so if you want a flawless game you may be disappointed, but it's fun to play nonetheless.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFinally. The fighting games us PC smashers have been waiting for. This game is nothing short of fantastic, even in its early stages. It combines the thrilling and exciting gameplay of Melee with the accessibility of Smash 4, which makes it a perfect medium. The gameplay is smooth, the controls are solid and they even let you change them to your preference. Online is great because it plays out as a best 2/3 set against your opponent (the format in which a majority professional Smash sets are played out). Overall, a must have for fans of the Super Smash Brothers series, and fighting games alike. Pick it up today!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An absolutely amazing Smash-Like Fighting game. Super tight controls, 1v1 netcode, intriguing and ingenious characters, cool maps, and tons of fun to be had.

Every character has a unique gimmick, whether it be spreading flames of doom, covering the map in smoke and creating a smoke clone, leaving a puddle on the ground so that one may teleport to, and more!

Maps have two modes; Aether and Normal. In aether mode, things can get crazy. Chunks of the map can be destroyed, a ferris wheel goes round and round, and plants bite your bleeding head off!

Early Access? The very definition of it! You're not getting some barely-playable Alpha. You're getting a polished and content-filled early-access version of the game. You're literally getting it before it's released! There are two characters left to be added, Absa and another unknown one. 4 maps are currently in, each with Aether Modes. I think the plan is 8 maps, can't recall.

Beware if you're in Australia or places with terrible internet, you may not have too much fun without local friends to play with.

It's Great! Oh and by the way, it is pretty hard. Skill-based, y'know?

reviewText:

Indie? Platform Fighting? 8 charachters? Retro Graphics?
Do you think it is a bit weird as of 2015-2016 to read such description?
Well... don't fear. this game is all that above - and it is wonderful.
Designed to be a less casual\more competitive Smash Bros. this game nails it perfectly. the graphics are charming, playing is swift and sounds are nice. the roster is pretty well balaced. It is tons of fun in short little matches that take no longer than 10 minutes. It takes some hours to get the feels of the game - untill them expect to get whomped online... but after some hours of practice you will start to fight properly and games online will be a thrill - not easy at all - but fun anyways.
I wasn't so sure about buying a game in early development stage, but this guy d4nace who is the chief developer behind RoA has done a wonderful job and the game is quite complete as of now! it'll in fact only gain functions as time goes by.i bought it in a promotional price, quite cheap - but it is definitely worthy of its full price!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is really well done for a game maker game.
Each character has it's own gimmick and unique feel, such as Maypul relying on her seeds or Orca relying on his water puddles.
Each character has it's own benefits and niche in the meta game, so anyone can be op if used right.
Of course, that isn't to say i'm a pro, since I neglect to use my shield or dodge with it.
If the game ever does try to imitate smash in more ways, I will be glad, because that would mean I can try and grab instead of stupidly attacking someone when they're shielding and end up suffering for it.
Then again, that's what makes the game good competitive wise, since any mistake you do can lead to your death and same for your opponent.
Overall, 9/10. Waiting for story mode since i'm one of THOSE people.

Where do I begin? This game is basically Smash Brothers for Steam! It mixes game play from Smash 64, Melee and Smash 4 for Wii U/3DS, from combo options to techniques such as Wave dashing from Melee and easy to learn controls from Smash 4 and even new features that keep this game fresh and original!

I'd definitely recommend this to veteran and even new players to the Smash community or people who want to try something new, my wallet wasn't even crying when I purchased this, well worth the price for what it has to currently offer and what it will offer in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After about 200 hours playing this game, it's probably the most fun I've had playing a fighting game. Very easy to pick up, hard to master completely. Teaching my friends how to play was a breeze and close matches are pretty much a give in. I've never really been interested in fighting games until RoA.  Balancing in the game has been extremely fair and it feels like most characters get smoother and better with each update, except for the occasional couple of bugs. None of which have been absolutely game breaking for me.

If you're on the fence, then trust me it won't hurt to try it out. You WILL get sucked into it though, so keep track of your playtime.

If you have lag issues, try port mapping 1972 and 1973. I used to have a lot of dc issues, but after openining these ports, it solved my problems.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Remember when Brawl came out and a billion low effort, cheap or free-to-play clones of it were released? With a scant few characters with very little to set them apart from each other and very poor balancing?

Rivals of Aether is not one of those games.

Rivals is a game designed by and for fans of the SSB franchise who want a platform fighter that plays to the strengths of the more fast-paced and competitive entries in the series, particularly melee. It is built upon the foundation of the competitive melee community, even using a default ruleset that emulates that of melee tournaments (best of 3 sets, set to timed stock matches) and takes many techniques that are central to melee gameplay and encourages them (where the later smash bros games removed them).

That isn't to say that this game is only for competitive melee players or even for people who enjoy melee - it brings a great deal of new and innovative gameplay concepts to the table by designing each character's moveset specifically around their effects on the stage itself (Wrastor's whirlwind allowing him to move faster and be more dominant, Zetterburn's flames allowing him to lay traps, Orcane's allowing him to move around the stage at will). If you enjoy any of the smash bros games, you should enjoy this. It's a great game for both casual players and competitive players looking for a quick fix.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At least read the whole thing.
Rivals of Aether is a Super Smash Bros. like game centered more around a recreation of Smash Melee. This game is not worth it if you're starting off or you're a casual player. Unless you are very experienced with compettitive smash-like games, you're pretty much playing locally for a very, very, long time. Don't get me wrong, this game is very fun, and if you can get a bunch of friends with you, play this with them.
But if you want to play online and you're inexperienced, good luck not getting your a%$ boiled by Zetterburn.

Coming from a casual like myself, Rivals of Aether gets a 4/10 for online, and a 7/10 for local.

Coming from a competitive player's viewpoint, you'll get a kick out of this game, but stick with smash, Rivals of Aether would get a 8/10 for online, and a 9/10 for local.



As for Steam, personally I reccomend this to players who are experienced with the Competitive Melee scene, but, as a casual, I'm can't recommend this game to someone starting off. The game definitely has an audience, it's just not for us casuals.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals of Aether is like Super Smash Bros. Melee with online, better features for serious play and a combat system that requires skill and practice to become good at. The game has an original roster of characters (even though there isn't that many right now) who all have different moves. Some of them could also be compared to characters from Melee. For example, Zetterburn is similar to how Fox plays in Melee and Wrastor is similar to how Falco plays (THAT AIN'T FALCO).

If you come from a Super Smash Bros background, then this will feel right at home. While the game does have a steep learning curve, it is very fun to learn and even more fun to play.

I would recommend this to anyone who has played a fighting game before. For people who haven't, I would recommend trying a game similar to this, like any Super Smash Bros game or Brawlhalla (which is free on Steam).

Rating: 7.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't spent too much time with it, but I wanna give you my two cents anyway.
Bear in mind, this is early access and right now there is not that much to do. Story mode and other things are coming though. Might redo this review as time passes.

But for now this is a fun fighting game and deliberately reminiscent of Super Smash Bros., but has some mentionable differences. Most noticeable for me, theres no Block/Shield. You do have a parry though, which does lock your opponent for a moment if timed properly, but this is only rarely doable online, because right now you have to handle lag and thus input delay. That sucks for a fighting game, but might change in the future.

As for the mechanics themselves: The characters feel good and pretty distinguished. Every fighter has his very own style of moving, fighting and using their special attacks. Controls are, mostly, Smash-Bros-ish. There is DI, there is Aerial Dodge and there even is wavedashing, if your into it. Racking up combos does require some skill, but feels very rewarding so far. This game seems to be supposed to be competitive. No items, only a few environmental hazards and skill oriented gameplay. This might turn out to be a great game in the future, if the updates keep coming and the network-issues get resolved.

Up to this point it is a fairly fun game to kill time with a lot of potential.

It also removes those annoying things like edge-grabbing and shielding and replaces shields with a parry technique that if successful will increase the lag of your enemy's attacks allowing you to go for the killing blow. For the Melee/Project M fans; Don't worry, your Air-Dodge and Wave-Dashing is here too.

For the characters, you will see that similar movesets you would find on other Smash characters like Zetterburn have melee attacks and Up special to Wolf from StarFox, Orcane similar to Vapereon from Smash Land, Kragg having attacks similar to Bowser, Donkey Kong and Sonic and Wrastor with similar attacks to Falco and Captain Falcon. If you are familar with those characters then it might be easier for you to get used to them, as if a slice of home has found you.

And unlike Smash 4 (at least in my experience) the online is not ♥♥♥♥♥♥ but you only do 1v1s which is fine because that's what I do anyway.

If you love Smash then you will love this.



Also if my Friends are reading this: Buy it, I want friends to play with....



It gets lonely.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You'll love this game if you love Smash Bros.
It has similar mechanics to Super Smash Bros Melee, but you can't grab
edges and players, and you preform counters instead of shields.

So far there are 6 characters with 2 more on the way which is fine for
an indie game but I would still like to see more.

It has a very good soundtrack and very nice pixel style graphics.

---Stuff that I would like to see in the future---
-Improvment to online play (had terrible lag when fighting against random opponents. haven't tried with friends yet).
-To preform a Smash attack, you have to press a sepeate button. It would be nice if it worked like in Smash, where you tap the analog stick fast.
-Workshop support for levels would greatly increase the replayability.
-Some way for fans to submit ideas for new characters, so we wont be left with just 8.

Overall, I reccomend this game if you like Super Smash Bros or fun couchplay games.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor supposedly being in version 0.0.2 or however, it feels fully fleshed, at least in terms of moment to moment gameplay. Each character has a game-changer ability or two that can modify the playing field, from obscuring vision, teleportation, to adding additional blocks and platforms. The online matches are best of 3 and you can find a new opponent after a set, which is so much better than dropping out in smash 4 every time you want a fresh opponent. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hot damn is this game fun. Probably the best smash-like out there.

Balance is tight (very tight, in my opinion, although people will disagree,) physics feel just right, and it feels really good when you land a kill setup. What makes the game really shine, though, are the characters, each of which have something that make them feel totally unique and interesting (yes, even Zetterburn has some neat stuff.)

Since it's early access, the game is quite limited, though. The six characters never get old, and different playstyles can change up these characters dramatically, but the roster will feel very small to a lot of people. There's also only local multiplayer and online, with the only really single player option being against the ai, and the ai is pretty easy once you get a handle on the game.

Online could also use a bit of work, as the netcode doesn't feel spot on a lot of the times, and a few network glitches make it hard to find a decent game a lot of the time. Lots of people are also rage quitting right now, sometimes seemingly over nothing, but I guess there's no avoiding that.

If you want a solid smash game to play online, this is a very solid choice. If you're looking for stuff to do alone, though, it would be better to search elsewhere, or maybe wait until it's out of early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals of Aether is like Super Smash Bros. Melee with online, better features for serious play and a combat system that requires skill and practice to become good at. The game has an original roster of characters (even though there isn't that many right now) who all have different moves. Some of them could also be compared to characters from Melee. For example, Zetterburn is similar to how Fox plays in Melee and Wrastor is similar to how Falco plays (THAT AIN'T FALCO).

If you come from a Super Smash Bros background, then this will feel right at home. While the game does have a steep learning curve, it is very fun to learn and even more fun to play.

I would recommend this to anyone who has played a fighting game before. For people who haven't, I would recommend trying a game similar to this, like any Super Smash Bros game or Brawlhalla (which is free on Steam).

Rating: 7.5/10

The gameplay in Rivals of Aether is rather agressive, with the defensive mechanics comprised mostly of Don't get hit" and the new parry ability introduced in this game. Each character in this game varies widely from the last

helpfulPercent: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will say this, Rivals of Aether is my favorite Steam game as of right now. And the fact that it’s still in early access speaks for itself. With 195 hours logged in, as well as a decently high ranking on the NA PR, I decided that it’s finally time that I write a review.

For those of you that don’t know, Rivals of Aether is a platform-based fighter, similar to that of Super Smash Bros. However, each character has something ridiculous about them that totally wouldn't fly in your average Smash game. Certain gameplay mechanics such as parrying instead of shields, the lack of ledges and the lack of grabs allow for a much more aggresive playstyle than that of Smash. Some people aren’t a huge fan of this, which I can understand. Personally, I like going ham, and this game can definitely support that.

Probably my favorite thing about this game is the characters. Each character provides a very different, unique playstyle, which is way more than I can say for Smash. Besides that, as I said before each character has something ridiculous about them. However, the characters are very balanced, and every character is viable. This allows for a very interesting play on the battlefield.

In terms of stages, they are all very well done. Each play a different role in counter-picking, and should definitely be worth considering. Speaking of counter-picking, it’s worth mentioning that the local play mode has a striking system similar to that of Project M. So this allows for a better counter-picking system when participating in tournaments.

My only complaint is actually about that striking system. I have no complaints about it, except that it’s only in the local play mode. I would like it if this was in the online mode as well, or to be more exact, when playing online with friends. This allows for better practice on certain stages during friendlies, and allows for counter-picks during online tournaments.

Last but not least, a word for Dan. KEEP IT UP! This game is incredible, and I’m sure that you will do good for the game with every patch. And although I’m sure you’ve already got a plan for the 8th stage, I think it would be cool if we had a stage with no platforms, considering that’s something that every character has relied on in some way possible. If you’re already doing that, then good on you!

As for the reader, thanks for reading! This is definitely a game you should put on your wishlist at the very least, but keep in mind that once this game is out of early access, the price will rise! This is most likely the cheapest time that you’ll be able to get the game, so I’d try to get it ASAP. With that, I bid you farewell, and good luck on the battlefield!

It's Melee but on PC and includes some Sm4sh style stages for all you filthy casuals out there. I wouldn't recommend buying it right now, there's not much in it aside from local versus and online versus, but once it gets out of early access this game will be worth every penny.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I'll admit it. I suck at Melee. My Marth struggles to move fluidly and can't even combo spacies 1/1000 as well as M2K. But I sure can wavedash.
Rivals of Aether (ROA) is a  platform fighter that's heavily based off of the Smash Brothers franchise, but it has its own elements that make ROA very different, such as the lack of shields and ledges to name a few. I also believe that this games development is fully considering the competetive players. That's not to say that casual players such as a group of friends or family won't find it fun, as the core mechanics are easy enough to learn but hard enough to master to get the balance between ease and skill ceiling.
In my opinion, this game sits in the middle of Melee and Smash4, the two most played games of Smash Bros. It has the ability to become technical at times where combo heavy characters can flourish, like in Melee. But, there is also a much higher need for careful thinking before acting, like in Smash4. The recent inclusion of ranked play with leaderboards makes winning and losing count many times more than before. Finally, the ability for almost any controller or keyboard to connect and work is an absolute joy. I would not have bought this game if I could not use my GameCube controller with it (which will work with adapters, including Nintendo's. Just Google how to make it work.)
As for bugs and glitches, I can say only once has my game crashed and the bugs that I have not encountered are being taken out by the dedicated dev team.
Overall ROA sits comfortably as my favorite fighter to play (Melee and Smash4 still hold my eye for viewing) and I look forward to seeing the community grow both online and at tournaments.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: Okay, this game is a lot better when you turn on auto-run. It has different problems that still make me not reccomend it. The hitstun is so high, it makes it really easy to be combo'd to death and back. The game is still fun, but it's impossible to play online because of the constant input lag. It can be up to two seconds and make the game impossible to play. When this gets fixed, I'm sure the game will be great. Until then, it's not worth it.

EDIT 2: okay actually this game is REALLY fun with friends. If you have friends to play it with, it's great. All of the previous issues I mentioned still apply, but if you're playing with a friend, the connection is nice and stable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have sorely underestimated this game. I thought this game was going to be a lot like smash 4: a slow paced fighting game with few options to your movement. Instead, I get something that's more akin to project M (with fewer characters stages). It has wavedashing, dashdancing, and a indepth tutorial about its mechanics. There's no ledge to grab onto, but you can still edge guard once you get used to it.

DISCLAIMER: I'm not saying smash 4 is bad. I just don't like the game.

Highly recommend to any Smash Bros. fan or even fighting games in general!

Early Access Review

This game is awesome!

It's based off of Super Smash Bros (so it's in the same sub genre of this game). But it has its own unique gameplay mechanics that set it apart and make it a unique gameplay experience. If your a fan of Super Smash Bros, this game will provide a refreshing difference in playstyle. If you're not a Smash fan, then try out this game. It's a fun fighting game, that once you get into it, has a pretty balanced roster of characters and great competative play.

The only con that I have with this game is lag issue. It's not in every match but it's in enough to be mentioned.

I strongly recommend this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Only just starting, and I'm already in love.

It may at first seem like a super smash bros clone, but actually has a bit more unique character than you'd think. While it does borrow the same percentage/KO system from smash bros, the gameplay is a new animal entirely (no pun intended). No characters can grab the ledge, yet all can wall-jump, making recovery much more interesting and dangerous. No landing lag, allowing for a 0% to KO combos provided you don't miss any oppoprtunities. Unlike smash, you do not have any shield, and you can't grab. Instead, you parry
date:
Which is nothing like smash's defensive play at all. So far, Inturrupting a combo stream with a well timed parry is extremely satisfying.

If you are a fan of super smash bros (especially Melee and project M) I cannot recommend this highly enough. It was made by a smash bros fan with smash bros fans in mind. However, there are some things you should know. This is a competitive game. It does not have the party gimmicks (items and final smash moves). It's made to be a sport. Also, we're still missing 2 characters and the entire story mode. It is early access after all.

10/10 (so far)
I'm pretty sure I won't be playing anything else for a while.

EDIT: I learned how to do controller mapping!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBest Smash Clone Out There! .Absoutely amazing if you like competitive games, casuals can still play, but its designed for competitive (0 to plsStapCombos). It has a VERY ofensive kind of gameplay(There is no shield and no grab so all the momentum becomes offensive or neutral besides the parry stand).Early access compensates the lack of (in numbers) music,characters and stages repertory (but not in quality).There are 6 characters 5 stages and one stage song for each of one.(Very Catchy i should admit) Characters have a very unique moveset and all of them look great and feel somewhat balanced . The combat system is fresh and feels smooth so you can pull out very fancy combos without pressing a whole bunch of buttons. In overall a very solid experiencie. 4.0/5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Only just starting, and I'm already in love.

It may at first seem like a super smash bros clone, but actually has a bit more unique character than you'd think. While it does borrow the same percentage/KO system from smash bros, the gameplay is a new animal entirely (no pun intended). No characters can grab the ledge, yet all can wall-jump, making recovery much more interesting and dangerous. No landing lag, allowing for a 0% to KO combos provided you don't miss any oppoprtunities. Unlike smash, you do not have any shield, and you can't grab. Instead, you parry
date:
Which is nothing like smash's defensive play at all. So far, Inturrupting a combo stream with a well timed parry is extremely satisfying.

If you are a fan of super smash bros (especially Melee and project M) I cannot recommend this highly enough. It was made by a smash bros fan with smash bros fans in mind. However, there are some things you should know. This is a competitive game. It does not have the party gimmicks (items and final smash moves). It's made to be a sport. Also, we're still missing 2 characters and the entire story mode. It is early access after all.

10/10 (so far)
I'm pretty sure I won't be playing anything else for a while.

EDIT: I learned how to do controller mapping!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a lot like Super Smash Bros. Melee. There are no grabs or blocking, but all characters have can use a defense mechanic to nullify attacks and deflect projectiles. The characters themselves are individually more complex than any Smash character I've played, though the roster is small.
Controls are responsive and handle very smoothly.
Stages are mostly rather small, with no need for camera position and zoom adjustment, and they can be either static or dynamic.
The basic versus settings (stock, time) are intact, but there are no items.
This is a game for people who try to be good at Smash.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DISCLAIMER: This review is for the Early Access verion of RoA. Things are going to improve and be changed in the future.

As an avid Smash fan, I was extrememly excited for RoA. I even signed up for the beta and played the alpha builds a long time ago. To my unpleasant surprise, not much has changed.

Most of the game feels 'tacky' and rather lazy. The amount of options doesn't come close to matching up with flash projects such as Super Smash Flash or the like. The game has a very limited set of defensive options that don't allow for any creative leeway. That said, there's new mechanics, and they are interesting. Instead of implumenting a defensive shield-based system, Dan opted for a parry system. That's fine, new things ina 'Smash' scenario sound awesome.

The biggest problem is that the game has is it's way to defensive. The way the parrys work currently creates a heavy 'run in, do a combo string, then run the hell away' gameplan. Rinse and repeat.

After my time with the game it seems that the neutral is less about creativity and interesting approaches/follow ups and more about who messes up first and get's punished first. The footsies in the game are rediculious, and I'm sad the game is primarily that. I would have moved to have a better balance between character's defensive and offensive options.

As for reccomending this game, it's iffy. If you like Smash Bros. and have played it for years, I don't reccommend this. The design philosophy will feel foreign to you. For other crowds that want to get into fighting games, this might be a nice stepping stone to start with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Word of warning, I'm gonna use some Smash terms)
As someone who is a semi competitive Melee and PM player, this game really clicks with me. If you play Melee and PM at a high level, you can probably pick up a character in an hour or two. If you're a competitive Melee or PM player, you can probably pick up a character in an hour or two.


This game is ACCESSIBLE
The gameplay is fast and smooth, and incredibly user friendly. The learning curve is lessened from Smash due to the lack L-Cancelling, replacing it with low landing lag, making combos smooth and easier to perform. There aren't edges to the stages, making edge-guarding less read based, but, the wall jumping and air dodging lets you mix up your recoveries just enough to keep opponents guessing, but not to the point where you could do 3-4 different things recovering. Also, you can attack and move out of an air-dodge, which makes a missed wavedash off the stage less punishing. There aren't any shields in Rivals. Instead, you have parrying, which keeps defensive play to a minimum.

I haven't even talked about the characters yet.

Wow.

Every character is completely unique, with really well executed ideas. Zetterburn can set opponents on fire, and if he connects a strong attack (the non copywritten name for smash attacks) while the opponent is still on fire, the attack does quite a good deal more knockback and damage (Try aerial side-b into F-smash ;) ). Wrastor is the godlike combination of Falco, Marth, and Jigglypuff. He utilizes a wind current that, if he is inside it, raises his speed and his already insane aerial speed. He also has 4 jumps, so, uh.

BACK AIR BACK AIR BACK AIR.

Anyways, Forsburn can create a clone of himself (ICs anyone?) and can create smoke, store it, and use it to create an explosion around him. He can also Ken combo. Orcane uses a puddle that he creates somewhere on the map. He can teleport to it, make it evaporate into bubble has a trap, and enhance some moves of his. Maypul is an extremely small and fast character that can mark opponents with certain special moves. If she uses a strong attack while the person is marked, they are stunned for a small amount of time, which is a really simple kill setup. If the opponent is marked and she up-Bs, she will pull herself toward the opponent, and control her direction, which is great for mixups. Kragg hits quite hard, but is a good deal slower that the rest of the cast. He can create a big stone that he can throw in a myriad of directions. If he isn't holding it, he can break with an attack, which sends a bunch of rocks in the direction he attacked. Depending on what attack you use and what direction you hit it at. His up-B is really bizarre, he summons a pillar of stone wherever he is. It's really useful for comboing, by getting an opponent between Kragg and the pillar opens tons of combo opportunities.

So, is this game worth buying? Yes, absolutely, One of the greatest games in early access right now.

Hope to see you online!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please note that this game ISN'T a clone of Smash, its just inspired by it. If you took the time to play some more Rivals of Aether then you would notice that the game is very different then Smash. It has many unique mechanics that sets it apart from Smash Bros. Also i am aware that this game is still in development. this review is based on the 0.0.11 version of the game

-PROS-
-Every Character is very unique and has a different playstyle
-Very active devs and community
-Can easily edit the stats of the Rivals with the Dev mode
-No Shield and Grab mechanics
-visually appealing art style

-CONS-
-AI is very dumb
-only 7 Rivals
-Lots of modes that are locked for now
-only 5 stages

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've put a bit of time into this game and Brawlhalla as well, and because they are contantly in conversations together I will continue that trend and mention that game as I speak about this one.

Rivals of aether is an fun and amazing game very similar to the original smash bros. The game is complex but interesting and have a fair amount of character diversity to make the experience enjoyable. Compared to brawlhalla this game has the better formula, but it suffers from some major lag issues. Make sure to play this game with an ethernet cable at all times and if you play online watch the ping of the other player. If their ping isn't yellow don't bother playing them or else your match will be plagued with input lag.

Aethetically, the game isn't too pleasing and seems like an retro game (guess this appeals to some people), but if you're willing to overlook the oldschool graphics you have a whirlwind of fun coming at you. It is obvious this game isn't in full release which is evident in the limited online play. Currently, online is limited to only one vs. one as opposed to brawlhalla's typical four to eight player free for all. Hopefully the devs can fix the lag issue and improve the game's net code.

If you compare this game's characters to that of brawlhalla, brawlhalla has the larger roster. ROA's character roster may be smaller but every character feels unique and have their own unique move-sets. On the otherhand Brawlhalla's character slection is based a select seof weapons and every character have similar move-sets.

With all that being said, this game is exetremely promising and it's your go to game to get your fighting-game-fix. I recommend the game, but be warned that the game definately feels incomplete in its current form.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I play exclusively online, so the review applies to online play only.

If I wrote this review when the game first came out it would have been a thumbs up and a glowing review. But I cannot recommend this game as it has some serious flaws.

1. The netcode is atrocious and is not anywhere near appropriate for a fighting game. Inputs get dropped, input delay changes on the fly, and each player will experience lag differently. I have fought many times where the player I was fighting was getting lag and input drops but I didn't feel a thing, and vice versa.
2. The characters are way too gimmicky. This is very fun when you first play the game and you get to see how unique each character is, but eventually it becomes boring and turns into each character has one play style and X number of auto/near auto combos you must do to be competitive."
3. Due to the character gimmicks
date: the game is mostly about hard counters. It feels like most matchups are 7/3. For example
recommended: Zetteburn v Kragg is ridiculously in Kraggs favor.\n4. At an advanced level

votesFunny: Forsburn and Zetteburn uair & fair spam. You end up seeing and using the same combos over and over and over because they work. Originality only has a place in the very top % of players.\n5. The parry mechanic is an original idea with a terrible implementation. Parry is spammable
commentsCount: and landing a parry vs a player at a high % is essentially a guaranteed kill.\n\nIt's early access

column17: I'm putting this game down. The frustration of dealing with the subpar netcode and lack of balance vastly outweighs any fun."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even at the current update (0.14.0) I still cannot reccomend the game. I really wish I could I love the game but it seems like the devs have no idea how they actually want to balance the game. Every update tries to balance characters in meaningful" ways yet always seem to fall short. I wanted balance in my previous review but I was sadly wrong to believe that it would fix the game in any way possible.

Most of my past issues have been resolved though
date: you can now see other players ping before commiting to a match online. Leaderboard is nice along with the ranking system
recommended:
I really want to reccomend this game. But again every update changes the meta drastically (Sm4shish updates) there is really no reason to put any work into the game at this point if characters are going to change this much.

Final words
Taken from the Wrastor patch notes:

"For Wrastor
hoursPlayed:
we are still trying to balance him out by removing reliance on Tornado and spreading out his KO potential elsewhere."

When a character has a gimmick isn't normal for them to rely on said gimmick much like the other characters of the cast rely on theirs?
