reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not my type of game, controlls feel really floaty and i find it really hard to properly pace myself to even perform simple moves letalone proper combos.
Playing this on a fight sick is also a complete nogo while the button layout for controllers imo is horrendous, you have the ability to change controlls only while at the character select screen and even then you have to change them everytime you play somone else since it just reverts back.
I would only suggest this game to anyone if they really enjoy playing smash and only smash, comparing this to other fighters is just impossible.

other notes:

I really hate pressing a button to jump especially when its bound to Y. Sorry bethesda.

Playing with a fightstick i ran into the game still recognising stick imput ghosting, Hold stick right and let go it will still keep going for a few milliseconds after release even causing you to run off ledges right when the game starts if you just let it do its thing, i was able to recreate this problem 36/50 tries, it even does the same with the cursor in character select.

Only 2 people fighting at a time, for this kind of game i was hoping for 4 player combat.

Because of the way the controlls of the game work its alot of work to even position yourself properly to even hit your enemy and with most of the moves having these delays, just missplacing yourself out of reach to hit your enemy, a problem i haven't had in any fighting game including smash itself,

Playing a game is supposed to bring you excitement and you enjoy playing them, but with this all im getting is dissapointment that i wasted $15 on a game i probably would never play again based on its lackluster and barely working mechanics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a competitive Smash Bros player(#2 in my country) I think this game is insanely bad and I'm saying this because I've put 90+ hours into it. At first people think it's amazing and I also thought so but after around 30 hours you start to realize the game's issues. Bad mechanics, extremely bad character design and weird stages. Wouldn't recommend to anyone.

It DOES feel like a good game at first, don't get me wrong. But once you realize it's weaknesses you'll regret buying it and probably go back to Smash as soon as possible.

Okay, I can elaborate.

Bad mechanics:

Parry: Parry is a fighting game mechanic and it's good in some games such as Street Fighter series or Pokken, where it actually works. In a platform fighter like RoA however, it doesn't work. It's basically powershield but worse because smallest mistake can lead to a 0-death combo. If you're playing Smash 4, you know Bayonetta has a similar move called Witch Time which is essentially RoA parry. You know what happened when they added that move to Smash 4? Everyone got crazy over it and now they're considering actually banning Bayonetta because she has a parry. That's how BAD parry is in a platform fighter game. In these kind of games(RoA, Smash 4 etc.) there are moves which are high risk high reward, and low risk low reward. In Smash games, there are shields and if you commit to a low reward move, you'd expect to get punished lightly. But if you commit to a high reward move and get shielded, you'd expect to get punished heavily. In RoA, parry completely ♥♥♥♥♥ on this balance and makes every move high risk, because parrystun is the same even if the move is a high risk move, or a low risk move. This essentially makes the game extremely defensive, to the point where whoever hits first might get punished too heavily so both players would have to play too carefully. I don't see a high-level future for this game simply because of this mechanic.
Random meteor hitboxes: For the sake of making some characters go for crazy hype  meteors and stuff, all hitboxes that goes downwards were given a meteor hitbox. This makes characters like Zetterburn(up-b) or Kragg(nair) meteor the other characters randomly for no reason. Completely unintentionally too. This isn't too much of a big deal but I'd expect a fighting game to be a little more consistent. I like examples of games where you do things and those things work as you meant. In RoA that isn't the case.

Bad character design:

Absa and Orcane:The developer seems to be confused about how the game should be played. He makes zoning heavy characters that punishes approaches, then realizes these characters slows down the game and nerfs them. Shuts down what they have and makes them unusable in high level play. Absa got nerfed twice, and Orcane got nerfed three times. Their zoning tools got nerfed heavily, for no reason. These characters' movesets and designs all compliment to a zone-heavy defensive gameplan. Then he weakens them and buffs other tools they have to make them play more offensively. It doesn't make sense. Very bad design choices by dan fornace. (They should've stood the way they were)

Kinda tired of typing, I'll type more later.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA good game in theory, but it fails to deliver any true competition. The game is too easy to cheese and be good at, especially with how awful the online netcode is. Lag is a constant feature, and every character is too gimmicky to be worth it, just spam their special moves and eventually you win. The easiest way to win against anyone 1 on 1 is to simply sit underneath a platform, poke through with your moves and specials, and parry any attempt to attack you. There is literally no way to approach a campy and defensive playstyle with most characters. The characters are just bad rehashes of Super Smash Brothers characters, moves and all. And the characters that are most viable are simply the ones who can win off of two hits, special or otherwise.  Being badly balanced, poorly made, and featuring a lack of actual competitive viability killed this game.

Connections Issues is why I cant recommend this game, right now at least.

So far the game has been fun playing with friends, online with randos is a different story.  The competiton is even so far but about 1/2 games have disconnected mid way through a fight.  The lag will start then slowly characters freeze then you get hit with a disconnect.  Once the server issues have been fixed this game will get better.  This game is a blast when the servers arent having issues.  I have real solid internet so I know its not me.

Right now Im goin to not recommend this game.  If you are planning on playing random people online exclusively wait on this game, but local play is great.  Once server issues are fixed ill change my recommendation to yes.

Also, this game needs 2v2 or a 4 player free for all online mode desperately.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Want to experience the worst netcode in the history of online gaming? Do you enjoy balance philosophy that revolves around the phrase wouldn't it be cool if"? Then look no father!

Let me just start off by saying that I've been looking forward to this game for a long time. I was a frequent tournament-goer for Super Smash Bros. Melee years back
date: and after watching Nintendo ♥♥♥♥ up the following two entries in the series
recommended: I'm sure there were plenty of people like me who were excitedly anticipating a game in the same vein that was actually designed to be competitive. But alas
hoursPlayed: the excitement did not last long. But hey
voteText:
let's start with what's good.

Pros:
- The art style and sound design are pretty freaking great. There's obviously been a lot of love poured into the character sprites and animations and you can really feel it. The stages in kind are wonderfully detailed
helpfulPercent:
especially that giant plant who will ruin your day repeatedly on the treetop level. The music and sound effects all fit in with the aesthetic are are really a treat most of the time. My only complaint here is that some things are just a little too similar to Smash Bros. to the point where it feels less like "inspiration" and more like "copy paste".

- The game (at least when it's offline) runs just as smooth as you would hope it does. It's easy to link attacks together to create dynamic combos just like you would in Smash Bros. Landing lag is virtually non-existent so the game maintains a very fast pace that is certainly tailored to the preferences of Melee players like me. It's great.

Okay
votesHelpful: now let's move on.\nCons:\n- The netcode. Holy ♥♥♥♥ is it bad. It's like Super Smash Bros. Brawl all over again. If you want to get good at this game
votesTotal: you better learn how to play through a soft delay at minimum to 3+ second input lag at worst. Matches that actually feel smooth are so rare that when you finally get into one you'll start playing badly because you'll be so used to the lag. And with no way of seeing your opponent's ping before a match
votesFunny: you have no way of filtering your matches. "Early Access" isn't an excuse at this point when so many other Early Access games
commentsCount: especially ones like this that are born for online play
column16: have near perfect netcode right out of the gate. But hey
column17: maybe I'm just spoiled by the buttery smoothness of Rising Thunder's dream netcode.\n\n- Parrying. There are actually some huge key differences between this game and Smash Bros. that chance the way you play the game pretty radically. Number one is that there is no blocking or grabbing. That system is replaced entirely by parrying. Now on paper it seems like a good way to make the game a lot more aggressive and keep characters that would otherwise be way too safe on their toes. On paper. In application parrying makes the more defensive zone-control characters even more powerful than they would be if they just had a shield or even just a spot dodge. Why? Because unlike parries or perfect blocks in other games that just give you a frame advantage
column18: a successful parry in Rivals of Aether puts your opponent in a stun state that allows you to counter attack. This effectively means that unless you opponent is being juggled
column19: using ground attacks is suicide because you will simply be parried and destroyed. It doesn't bother Wrastor too much due to his heavy aerial emphasis
column20: but it screws over every other aggressive character and turns fights between defensive characters into an even slower affair where both sides are afraid to go in for the kill because one parry and they could be dead. It's a huge example of "cool idea
column21: terrible execution".\n\n- There are no ledges and instead everybody gets one wall jump that also resets their up special. This
column23: was clearly an attempt to make the game more exciting and aggressive but actually ends up removing a substantial amount of depth from the game. Now if you haven't played Smash Bros.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever wanted to play smash without having half the characters suck? well then this games for you.
Rivals of Aether is probably one of the best smash clones around ive got 44 hours on it nearly and im still enjoying every minute of it.
What makes Rivals of Aether stand out is that all the characters are able to add to the environment somehow or another whether its through leaving a fog you cant see into, a puddle that can be blinked out of or a giant pillar blocking the path.
This adds a very unique feel every match because everybody can use these skills differently.
Its got extremely satisfying sprites each with a plethora of recolours to choose from.
Each stage is made very well and making it so you can play each match a different way.
Pros:
Great Gameplay
Fantastic looking sprites
Unique Characters
Different feel to each stage
Has offline multiplayer
Tons of recolours
Fun Soundtrack
Great for casual play
Cons:
Its still very much being worked on
Online can sometimes be a pain with all the lag
No arcade mode yet
Bots kind of suck

All in all I would strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys smash or fighting games in general.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Anyone who like Super Smash Bros should play this game. Rivals of Aether is very fast-paced and brings back a ton of the great mechanics from Melee, while still having it's own unique playstyle. It's still in Beta and has a promising future, as the developers are extremely dedicated to the developement of this game. I honestly can't recommend it enough.

P.S.
I recommend getting a GameCube controller adapter to play this game. It's still playable with any other controller, but the GameCube controller just feels right. Especially if you have a background in Smash Bros.

This game feels terrible to play, nothing has weight to and the parry mechanic is just silly. I know I'm bad at the game and to be able to go online and take a win just because I can time my trigger button is stupid; I know nothing about these characters and I can hardly figure out recovering.

This game feels like a bad version of smash, Even if you like every other part about this game you'll still be thinking of smash bros. There are more platform-fighting games, like megabyte punch, that I didn't always have melee in the back of my head while playing. It's a genre that not many people have touched but that doesn't mean a game's defining characteristics need to be ripped from the largest success. Most everyone doing mechanical reviews of this game start off by comparing these characters to the ones in SSBM or Project M.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Haha! My first review on this account (Which is basically my 5th review, since this is basically my new old account [Oh, did I miscount? What? I've only done 3 reviews on my old account? READ PEOPLE'S DESCRIPTIONS DAMN YOU!!].), and I'm doing it on an indie game that goes by the name of Rivals of Aether.

**** KRAGG

Rivals of Aether is a brawler (Similar to the likes of Super Smash Bros.) which may only contain (at the moment) 7 characters to try out, but effectively creates a competitive atmosphere in the heat of battle (also, forgot to mention, this game is supposed to be aimed at mainly a competitive audience of brawlers, so don't be a 3 year old damn you).

Erm...I'm kinda at a loss of words here (brb getting passionfruit soda). Oh, I know! GAMEPLAY!

Each character has a vast array of moves they can use to defeat the opposition by hitting them so hard, they fly off the stage (also, forgot to mention, this game is heavily inspired off of Super Smash Bros, but no items. Ever.). So sit back, get a bottle of your favourite drink and snacks, and enjoy the rant (brb need moar passionfruit soda).

Each character has different attributes to their moves, so, for example,Absa's moves will not be the same as someone else like Kragg (**** KRAGG). Each character has the ability to double jump, but Absa's double jump is a weird float, kinda like Lucas from Super Smash Bros. Without using a controller (which is highly recommended), the basic controls are Z to attack, X to jump (yeah, wtf), C as special, D as taunt and Up, Down, Left and Right to move (Up doesn't make you jump, it makes your abilities aim upward). Depending on your character, these moves can be chained together into combinations of your moves, or known as combos" so you don't sound like a stupid. Respectively
date: each character also has aerial moves as well
recommended: which can also chain into their ground moves (see where this is going?). I'm not going over any combos

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This could be a fun game. I think that when Early Access is over, hopefully everything will be fixed.

What I mean by that is it has the POTENTIAL to be an extremely fun game. However, I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME... at least for the moment. I wouldn't feel right about pretending to recommend it.

About 1 in every 5 games do I have a connection that I can actually play without disruption. 8/10 games the connecton is so bad it freezes over and over again. Eventually someone will get sick of it and will purposefully suicide due to the terrible connection so that they can move on and hope they can connect to the next person.

Characters are simply imbalanced. There are a few that are just better than others. Better moves, stronger kill moves, more plentiful ways to combo that stun" long enough to not allow you to get out of it. It's just the way it is. This NEEDS to be fixed so that two players of equal skill levels don't lose to the other simply due to having a character with stronger attacks and better kill moves.

So no
date: don't buy this game. Don't give the developers any more money until they earn it. Character balance fixes
hoursPlayed: input lag fixes. All of this needs to be fixed before I can recommend Rivals of Aether.\n\nHowever
voteText: the few times that the connection is good and the characters in the current game aren't one of the imbalanced ones Rivals of Aether can be very fun. It's those VERY few times that keep me coming back every day. Hopefully I'll look back at this review and think
helpfulPercent: man I'm happy I kept playing."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an all around amazing game and i have picked it up because it appeared to be the same smash style I loved but at a cheaper price with different mechanics that make this game unique

PROS
- All new unique characters
- No relied upon mechanic of shieilding or grabbing but reverts to dodgeing instead
- Cheap
- Low PC requirements

CONS
- Very few characters
- Controls are hard to pickup
- People are very picky with who they want to face agaist online and will often disconnect after the first round or jump of the edge because you outplayed them in one of your three lives

However this game is extremely fun with very little learning curve to pick up and play but very difficult to master which gives it a great balance of easy fun and tough challenges
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game feels really nice and is overall super fun to play. If you enjoy playing Smash then I would take a good guess that you would most likely enjoy this game.
After putting more time into the game I can still say that this game is extremely fun. I feel that every character is viable and also fun to play which is how the developers created them.
Not only that but the developers care about the game and are updating it quite often seeing how several patches have been released recently. You can also run into developers in-game on netplay and can identify them by their blue name which goes to show that they put time into their game.
Although recently it feels that this game has died down quite the bit. It also feels like there's not that much to learn and that matches come down to who has the better side of the matchup more often than not.

tl;dr If you enjoy Smash pick up this for the low price and enjoy even though it has some flaws.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a blatant rip off of smash bros. This was obviously the vision that Dan Fornace had, but that doesn't make it a good vision. It contains all the basic movement from smash with nothing added. Even some of the characters have moves blatently taken from smash characters. This is unoriginal and if you like smash just PLAY SMASH. This game is a lazy attempt for the creator to make a bunch of money off of the fans of a great fighting game that already exists. Do yourself a favor, save the money, and get dolphin emulator for melee net play.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is everthing I want from a fighting game. In my opinion it is far superior to Smash 4, and is at least on par with Project M. Totally worth the money. Online is only laggy if one peson has a bad connection, and is otherwise flawless. Each charachter feels like a new experience, yet each seems familiar like an old friend from a past life. The diverse playstyles more than make up for the small roster size. This is a game made by Smash players, for Smash players. This is by far my favorite fighter of the year. Buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absa doesn't really make this game fun anymore... First of all, this lacks character choice creativity, because EVERYONE will choose Absa. Second, the character balancing was fine until Absa came along, not that I'm saying Absa should be removed. Finally, it may be just me, but from what Dan Fornace said on Twitter, making a weak character would NOT rise up the percentage. There wouldn't really be a reason to make a character in general. Again, it may be just me. I will still recommend this game, but I feel the game's popularity is wearing thin.

PLEASE NOTE THIS IS MY SOLE OPINION IN THIS GAME. I do not intend to burn this game to the ground.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A warning to casual players: this game's matchmaking system does not take skill level into account. This creates a frustrating and extremely unwelcoming environment for new players, who will consistently be matched with significantly better players. I would not recommend this game unless you fit into either of these categories:
You know someone who is about as skilled as you, and with whom you can have an enjoyable experience.
You are willing to dedicate yourself to this game and be a try-hard.

Look, I like this game. I really do. It's taking the smash bros. style of platform fighters and taking it somewhere very interesting. It's wonderful

But I don't live near a lot of people, and I don't invite anyone over to play games at my house. So I have to be completely online

I cannot reccomend this game online because on my very, very stable internet connection, there's input lag and match derops. Now, I don't mean Oh
date: two or three frames won't hurt you" kind of input lag. I mean that I have lost entire games
hoursPlayed: because I used my side smash in the wrong direction
voteText: because I have to hold the stick up or down so much longer than I would ever have to otherwise. I can't seem to parry at the right time
helpfulPercent: I'll drop my combos randomely
votesHelpful: I've even lost the set beause the one time I finally got Wrastor to down smash it was too late and I had to use my jumps to get back on stage... Except my jump button stopped working.\n\nAnd these are all problems inside of the online system. On the outside
votesTotal: I have lagless matches dropped at complettely random points
votesFunny: and I know they're not dc'ing. I've also been matched up against the same afk person 10 times in a row
commentsCount: whcih gets even worse because the countdown timer stops working for no good reason.\n\nPolish
column16: like menu screen music and an adventure mode
column17: aren't necessary. This game has everything that counts
column20: and a lot of really fun stuff. The polish can come towards the end of early access. But If you can't guarantee certain parts of functionality with the game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Considering this is a game very much like the Super Smash Bros. franchise, this review may be slightly biased. I am a very big fan of fighting games, and the Super Smash Bros. series as a whole. Nevertheless, here is my review.

It feels like Smash for GBA, which is pretty suiting, considering Dan Fornace's last game based off of Smash was in a Game Boy-esque style. The characters, soundtrack, stages and sprites feel very original, while still having that feel of nostalgia, as well as reminding you that this game is, basically, a Smash game. This is probably the best brawler for PC, and will probably be one of the best fighting games on the Xbox One when it releases later this year. That being said, the game is still in Early Access, meaning it is not finished. Personally, I can't wait until the full game comes out so I can try out the Story and Abyss Modes.

The game can be played in many different ways. You can play casually or competitively, with friends or without, online or offline, and you can also try one of the two minigame modes, Story Mode and Abyss Mode, once the full game comes out on Steam and Xbox One. It definitely isn't hard to find people, with the online mode to play with friends or random people across the world, and tournaments that will surely be hosted at the level of Smash tournaments, or at least close to it. The game is also relatively cheap, with a price tag of CDN $16.99 (for all of the Americans reading this, or for citizens of other countries, do the math). It also has full controller support, making for more hand room for you and your friends and more fluid gameplay. Rivals of Aether may not have the best graphics, but it makes up for it with fast-paced and easy-to-pick-up fun.

Overall, Rivals of Aether is a great gaming experiene. Whether you are looking to get good at the game, or just looking for a good fighting game on Steam, OR just looking for a good time with your friends and family, Rivals of Aether is the game for you.

- Parker Jamieson a.k.a. Elowex, YouTuber and owner of E-Miibo

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRIvals of Aether (ROA) were do i begin. This game is a smash meele inspired game. Some mechanics form meele are here but some of have not. The fighting sytem is similar due to this,however the game is very unique. Each charecter (7 total soon to be 8 at least for now) has their own unique moves an ways to combo them aswell as some type of gimick an not a bad gimick. for example Zetteburn can put fire on the stage and throw fireballs at u which if u touch it or get hit by it u will recieve a burn and for the time it last u take small damage and hiw strong attacks luanch u further. This makes every charecter different and no character is just a clone of another. If u enjoy any of the smashj games u will love this game. due to this being an indie game an the lack of people u know about it those that do play it are very high level players mostly pooring in form smash so u may feel outclassed in the online mode so get gud. i love this game and it deserves more recognition i give it a 9/10. it has some balanceing problem but no charecter is ever rediculousy over powered so the game is still amazing to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever wanted to play smash without having half the characters suck? well then this games for you.
Rivals of Aether is probably one of the best smash clones around ive got 44 hours on it nearly and im still enjoying every minute of it.
What makes Rivals of Aether stand out is that all the characters are able to add to the environment somehow or another whether its through leaving a fog you cant see into, a puddle that can be blinked out of or a giant pillar blocking the path.
This adds a very unique feel every match because everybody can use these skills differently.
Its got extremely satisfying sprites each with a plethora of recolours to choose from.
Each stage is made very well and making it so you can play each match a different way.
Pros:
Great Gameplay
Fantastic looking sprites
Unique Characters
Different feel to each stage
Has offline multiplayer
Tons of recolours
Fun Soundtrack
Great for casual play
Cons:
Its still very much being worked on
Online can sometimes be a pain with all the lag
No arcade mode yet
Bots kind of suck

All in all I would strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys smash or fighting games in general.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game feels really nice and is overall super fun to play. If you enjoy playing Smash then I would take a good guess that you would most likely enjoy this game.
After putting more time into the game I can still say that this game is extremely fun. I feel that every character is viable and also fun to play which is how the developers created them.
Not only that but the developers care about the game and are updating it quite often seeing how several patches have been released recently. You can also run into developers in-game on netplay and can identify them by their blue name which goes to show that they put time into their game.
Although recently it feels that this game has died down quite the bit. It also feels like there's not that much to learn and that matches come down to who has the better side of the matchup more often than not.

tl;dr If you enjoy Smash pick up this for the low price and enjoy even though it has some flaws.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game, It's the greatest smash inspired game to ever come out. The game is extremely smoosth and unlike other smash like games, this one does it right.

Pros

Great gameplay and mechanics.

No sheilding creating more offensive play.

Few characters, but all are unique and fun with none of them being too OP (Krag is not that bad people)

The stages are interesting and fun to play on with both a tournament/competitive version and a fun casual weird style.

All characters have something unique about them and are each easy to pick up but hard to master.

The game includes wavedashing but unlike melee it's not needed to be a good player, just there if you would like to play more competitively.

The movesets of the characters are things you would never see from a traditional smash game, making it see one of a kind.

Great servers and online connection, very little lag if any, the only type of lag would be from you having a bad internet, not the servers.

Cons

Not as many characters as I would like, though they will be brought in eventually.

Even the level 9 AI is easy to beat, making online the only real place to practice, and if you're downloading something then it might suck.

No way to see players steam profile after a match if you want to friend them to have a good practice partner.

These are all minor complaints for what is a fantastic game, from someone who is highly into the competitive smash scene(Going to local tournaments and practicing online constantly) I have to say that I like this game more than smash. It's easier to pick up, and with less character and more room to focus on each match up, much easier to get into competitively.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very interesting! I look forward to seeing how this develops in the future, and I'll be sure to play this with friends.

You probably found this if you're a Smash Bros player, in which case you know you're in for some Melee flavored action with a unique spin.
If you're not familiar, then you should know that this is a kinda niche title. It still has content that would be good for parties, but if you plan on getting into it more, you'll be seeing a lot of Smash terms.

You should also know that it doesn't support Gamecube controllers right now, and I don't know if it's planned, but you CAN get it working flawlessly with x360ce.

Ideally I would like to see that support, optimizations in the engine, and little quirks (like Maypul's dair and Orcane's fair not showing hitboxes in training) fixed

I do think this is a stellar release, though. The fighting is fun immediately and the characters have thoughtful design. The training mode settings are great and the attention to detail and certain design choices show that the developer has competitive play in mind. I think this has the potential to really go somewhere if it catches on.

BUT if you're not into Smash, I can't say I recommend it as of the initial release.
Pretty awesome if you do like Smash.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far so good. Fans of competitive Smash will find that this feels pretty much how you think it should. It took me maybe 30 minutes to acclamate to an Xbox One Controller, but after that the game is a blast.

-Things you're probably curious about-

Air-dodging works kind of like Smash-4. You can air dodge only once before touching the ground, but you are able to input commands after the air dodge. this works great for escaping combos and then being able to retaliate mid air. Wave-dashing is also in this game, but with the air dodge mechanics you can't kill yourself by missing a Waveland off the edge, which is a plus.


The hitstun feels a lot like Smash 64, making combos feel extremely clean, but the percent dealt by comboing moves has been adjusted accordingly. L-Cancelling has been done away with, but aerials have very low landing lag, so air -> ground comboing still feels fluid.


Character selection is currently expectedly low, with only 6 currently playable, but don't let that scare you away. As of writing this, the 3 hours I've put into this game (all in the surprisingly good online play) has been with a single character. Also, since this is still early access, you can be sure to expect new characters in the future.

All in all, an incredibly good game, it takes the groundwork that the Smash games built, and puts it into a competitively-aimed game with remarkable results. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was a bit annoyed at first by the clunky keyboard controls. Plugged in an xinput controller, figured out how to change the controls on the controller to fit my SSB4 settings and this was the result:
-Fresh 2D gameplay
-UNIQUE character gameplay (hardly any skill overlaps, loads of fun mechanics and counterplay)
-Not too much imbalance. Fire does a bit more than I'd like as it basically makes a huge danger area for no reason at all.
-Easy to learn (after about an hour or two) but near impossible to master.

Negatives? Sometimes you are matched with the same 3 people with like 550 ping. Annoying. Also no chat, double edged sword right there. Less toxic, also less banter between people who want to compliment each other.

This is a game in ALPHA 0.0.2 or something. It FEELS finished.
With some new modes and a snazzy ranked system which allows you to dodge games with crazy pings, this game will be well worth it. Still have to test local party mode, looks fun.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI am pleasantly surprised by how good this game feels to play. I only picked up the game on a whim after a friend recommended it to me, and I am very glad that I did. The gameplay feels a bit like PM; it has a very solid and fast paced, brawl style gameplay, with a low skill floor but a much higher skill ceiling. I've only put a few hours into the game so far, but I've been very pleased with the gameplay so far, and judging by how much I've enjoyed the game, there are many more hours of enjoyment to come.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI highly recommend this game for smash veterans and anyone in general interested in this style of competitive fighter. The game's mechanics are incredibly smooth, There really aren't too many balance issues (besides maybe Kragg, but still he's really slow so), and all of the characters are really unique. For an early access build, The game feels complete competitively, with netplay accessibilities that run decently. I could foresee lots of lag in areas with low ping, but thankfully I do not have that issue. The price is only going to get higher the longer you wait, and the players are only going to get better the longer you wait, so I would advise you buy it as soon as you want, but preferrably during the earliest part of the early access release. Have fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals of Aether is a breath of fresh air. It's got that retro atmosphere to it, but it's fast and furious, which makes it fun to play AND fun to watch. It has a small roster size, but that's probably a good thing, because it means it's much easier to balance the characters.

It's inspired by the Smash Bros. series, and it's very obvious that the creators love those games. Rivals of Aether feels a lot like Melee, but adds some unique touches of its own to make it stand out. I love it so far. If you like Smash Bros., and would like to play something similar, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While you may think that this game looks like an uninspired clone of Smash Bros, it is actuallly a quite original and high quality game.
The mechanics for each character are very unique and would likely never be found in a smash bros game. For example, the character Wrastor can perform strong attacks (smash attacks) in the air while the character zetterburn can set you on fire in order to activate his sweet spots for his attacks. Recovering to the stage is also very different from smash bros as ledgegrabbing is not in this game. This causes you to be very creative with your recovery and rely on walljumps to get back to the stage. Other differences include parrying instead of shielding and a lack of grabbing.
Even if you have put in countless hours into Smash Bros, you will find a fresh and enjoyable experience with Rivals of Aether. The game is smooth, fact, and filled with satisfying combos. Rivals of Aether feels less like a smash bros clone and more like an entry to the platform fighter genre. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys smash bros or fighting games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is spectacular. Would recommend to all Smash Brothers fans and fighting game aficionados across the Steam platform. Take a break from Street Fighter and Tekken and play a game where you can make your own combos with such a small amount of moves; plus, it's a break from the ultra-realistic 3D gore and special effects. ^^;

My second time trying out a game such as this (after prior experience with Smash Brothers' replicas such as Super Smash Flash 2), I was exepcting something less impressive or similar to all the others. The controls are easy to adjust to and pick up, especially if you're using an XBOX PC controller, then it plays like a dream. The pixel-art is amazing, kudos to all those involved in this game, amazing animation and stage design. The characters, I thought there would be at least one or two characters I wouldn't want to play with, but after around a few hours of gameplay, I'm comfortable with them all. The moveset for each character is rather unique; no repetition whatsoever. Hopefully, other online modes will be available in the future, but hey, baby steps. This is only early access and I'm already impressed. I procastinated over my homework to play a couple more hours of this game. I can see that there are some suggested features but not available for choice. Such as 'Online' in the options menu and the other spaces in the character roster. I'm most looking forward to Story Mode and Aether Mode; curious as to how this will be executed.

:)

Still hard to believe this was made in Gamemaker:Studio.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is based of Super Smash Bros. Melee AKA Best Smash game. The available cast is small but unique with each characters having their particular mechanics and styles of play. It incorporates some of the adanved techniques found in Melee like Dash Dancing and Wavedashing (Which is made incredibly easier to perform). L-cancel isn't present as the landing lag is very low in general. The combo game is top notch making his game one that you would spend hours practicing and performing combos. Story mode and Abyss mode are not available yet and 2 characters have yet to be announced officially.

Verdict: As it stands, Rivals of Aether is a stellar and fun addition to the growing Platform Fighter genre. It is a satisfying game with the components that made Super Smash Bros. Melee such a fun game with great retention value that made the game played all the way up to this day. A great gateway game into the Smash inspired Platform Fighter genre.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is a fantastic game. It combines all the technical aspects of Super Smash Brothers with a very fast and dynamic gameplay. The characters are all so unique in multiple ways with creative and diverse move sets. Not to mention the graphics are a beautiful 16 bit throw back and the music is also a wonderful 16 bit throw back aswel. A few minor dislikes I have with the game is that it needs more characters and stage selection but considering this game is in beta I have a feeling more will be on their way. Lastly I find that this game is almost unplayable by the general public without a controller. It's keyboard controls aren't very good and I had to buy a controller for this game. Beside those minor downsides I would recommend this game to smash fans or people looking to get into a competitive game.

Early Access Review

This game plays a lot like Super Smash Bros. Melee, with just enough changes to the mechanics to avoid being an outright clone. This comes highly recommended to fans of smash bros.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is amazingly fun. Along with it being fun it is very unbalanced. The characters are very fun and diverse but only a few have problems. Orcane can spam attacks and along with that his attacks do a whole bunch of damage. Kragg before the new update could do this as well. Forsburn isnt all that good of a character his attacks are slow and hard to pull off. Wrastor is a very good character because although his combo set might be a lot better than most of any of the other characters, its actually hard to pull off and feels rewarding unlike orcane where you can just spam it the whole time. Maypul is the same as Wrastor in terms of being a lot more fair. Zetterburn is very mixed. His attacks do a lot of damage but along with that his attacks are extremely easy to block. Orcane can block almost anything, rarely dies because of the ink/water that he can use to send him on the stage again. Speaking of stages they all feel to small for what the game is trying to pull off. Overall the game is very good, along with its minor flaws A.K.A spammable attacks, hard to play characters and small maps. This game gets an 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals of Aether is a breath of fresh air. It's got that retro atmosphere to it, but it's fast and furious, which makes it fun to play AND fun to watch. It has a small roster size, but that's probably a good thing, because it means it's much easier to balance the characters.

It's inspired by the Smash Bros. series, and it's very obvious that the creators love those games. Rivals of Aether feels a lot like Melee, but adds some unique touches of its own to make it stand out. I love it so far. If you like Smash Bros., and would like to play something similar, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is spectacular. Would recommend to all Smash Brothers fans and fighting game aficionados across the Steam platform. Take a break from Street Fighter and Tekken and play a game where you can make your own combos with such a small amount of moves; plus, it's a break from the ultra-realistic 3D gore and special effects. ^^;

My second time trying out a game such as this (after prior experience with Smash Brothers' replicas such as Super Smash Flash 2), I was exepcting something less impressive or similar to all the others. The controls are easy to adjust to and pick up, especially if you're using an XBOX PC controller, then it plays like a dream. The pixel-art is amazing, kudos to all those involved in this game, amazing animation and stage design. The characters, I thought there would be at least one or two characters I wouldn't want to play with, but after around a few hours of gameplay, I'm comfortable with them all. The moveset for each character is rather unique; no repetition whatsoever. Hopefully, other online modes will be available in the future, but hey, baby steps. This is only early access and I'm already impressed. I procastinated over my homework to play a couple more hours of this game. I can see that there are some suggested features but not available for choice. Such as 'Online' in the options menu and the other spaces in the character roster. I'm most looking forward to Story Mode and Aether Mode; curious as to how this will be executed.

:)

Still hard to believe this was made in Gamemaker:Studio.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Game, where do i start? It is a brawler on PC, and its a good one at that, (unlike brawlhala, fight me). I have been searching for a game like this to just screw around with my friends on. Duck game was a good time waster but got stale after awhile, even though i keep coming back for more. Brawlhala went the direction of a F2P model, which i disliked. This game however, is sitting pretty in my library.

Rivals of Aether is a game most comparable to a mix of all of the iterations of Smash brothers. Though it is in early access, dont let it mislead you, it feels finished, but with some extra modes and characters coming later in this game's life. The characters are what make Rivals of Aether so great, so let me get into them

Zetterburn -
if you have ever played project m, this guy is basically wolf. Fast, powerful, a great projectile, and combos like no other.
Kragg -
id like to compare kragg to a wierd bowser  with the combo potential of project m and smaash 4 sonic, who also has arguably the best zoning tools in the game.
Orcane -
this guy is wierd, nothing i can compare hime to, he uses a puddle of some substance to manipulate his attacks and zone others out into the air for combos
Forsburn -
Ice climbers + melee marth = beauty
Maypul -
this guy has a lot of moves based on olimar but no seperate entity besides a plant that can trap opponents in place, very fast, and great arieal game
Wrastor-
this  guy was made if falco and jigglypuff had a baby, and it was adopted bu Captain Falcon.

and an upcoming character named Absa
who looks to be like the most technical and best zoning character in the game

all wrapped with online that is good, but sometimes fickle

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals Of Aether is a taste of Melee tech mixed with a more accessible and colorful cast of characters.
I've spent some time playing and following different streams, and everyone seems to think that a different character is OP. This indicates to me that the game is pretty well balanced. While a cast of 6 may seem slightly underwhelming, there are no clones and each Rival has a very unique playstyle with special setups. This means that the player is likely to play all of the characters with equal interest, as opposed to solely maining one in any another fighting game.
The soundtrack is very reminiscient of the SNES days, and the pixel art and animations are cute and pleasing.
Rivals already has me hooked, and it's only in alpha. I highly recommend it.

The characters are all developed in depth with different abilitites making the small pool of characters available understandable. The gameplay is adtoundingly fun and I find myself doing quick matches in between homework or chores or whatnot. If you have any doubt about buying this game, watch the videos of gamelplay on youtube while the game is installing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is extremely good. I love absolutely everything about it. I have the most fun going up against my friends who are around the same skill level as I am.

However, there is two things I'd like to bring up, which would be the online matchmaking. First thing's first: every single time I'd come on to play against people online, a combination of these things would happen: the game was extremely laggy (Smash Bros. Brawl laggy), the opponent I was going against was INSANELY good, destroying me within seconds of the match starting, or matches wouldn't start at all due to some sort of glitch that has players stuck in the character select screen.

I think a skill level system should be implemented, since fighting against those really good players has completely turned me off from the game's online; it made the game un-fun and absolutely infuriating when every match I'd have a Zetterburn or Forsburn that completely dominated me.

I'd also noticed that sometimes my control schemes weren't saved, so when I enter an online match, it'a really awkward to see that I had no clue what the jump button and attack button were (sometimes even the move buttons). I use an Xbox controller, by the way. Not sure if it's the controller or the game that doesn't save my control schemes but I would like to see it updated so that they're saved; it would be a great help.

Despite being an Early Access game, Rivals of Aether has blown me away with how fulfilling it is. I would recommend anybody who likes games similiar to Smash Bros. to buy this game NOW. Even if you don't like fighting games, BUY THIS FRIGGIN' GAME! I'm not even sure what genre Smash Bros. is, since it really isn't a TRUE fighting game, but it's not a pure brawler either. It's one of those rare little games you can't find very often. Rivals of Aether and Smash Bros. are definitely that type of game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's get one thing straight: this is no basic Smash clone. This game is something special. Do yourself a favor, and don't bother reading this review. Just play the game, Schneebly!
But for those of you who don't trust vague suggestions from random strangers on the internet:

I have never been huge on fighting games. I loved Smash, but in moderation. I have also dabbled in Marvel vs Capcom, MUGEN, Skull Girls, and some others. This game single-handedly piqued my interest in the competetive fighting game scene. I followed this game for at least a year, tracking its development. Within the first day of playing Early Access, I was hooked on studying the strategy, getting to know the characters, and learning the ins-and-outs of how to beat the tar out of my friends.

The game is amazingly deep and strategically complex for a 2D brawler, and I am hooked. I spent the better part of yesterday playing with my friend, just battling 1v1 over and over and over. We barely changed characters in between.

Graphics: Awesome pixel art. Super reminiscent of my favorite SNES games, but somehow prettier. 9/10

Animation: Gorgeous. Smooth. Hits are satisfying, motion is believable, characters have weight, playing looks and feels perfect. 10/10

Controls: Simple, but lots of possibilities therein. Control mapping is totally customizable. Characters are responsive, feels great. 10/10

Gameplay: Addicting. So, so addicting. Will be a perfect 10 after the release of more gamemodes, but in EA, it easily gets a 9/10

Features: So much strategy. Characters are incredibly unique and have the COOLEST movesets I've ever seen in a fighting game. As a zoning character, Orcane alone blew my mind, Kragg is my personal favorite, but each character has such a uniqe, creative, impressive, amazingly tactical moveset that greatly caters to their individual strengths and weaknesses. Zetterburn feels a bit overpowered at times, but overall the characters are very well evenly matched in the hands of capable players.  10/10

BUY IT!! Support the developers of this amazing indie game. I cannot stress enough, if you have ANY interest in fighting games, you will LOVE Rivals of Aether. Strongly reccomended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rivals of Aether is a Fire Emblem fighting game where characters that have the move Aether fight each other.

Rivals of Aether (ee-thur) is a Super Smash Bros. inspired fighting game with tight controls, cool movesets, and combo centric gameplay. This game is fun if you are playing for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles, but can sometimes be frustrating so bring a salt shield.

There are a couple of characters I believe need tweaking and balancing like Zetterburn and Forsburn and maybe Kragg, but other than that the characters are all balanced, but they each require huge skill to be decent with. I recommend using Zetterburn for transitioning players from smash to get used to how the game works and moves. FYI, you can wavedash for those who know what that is.

There are 6 characters at the time of this review, and those characters are  Zetterburn	 and  Forsburn	 (the Fire characters),  Kragg	 and  Maypul	 (the Earth characters),  Wrastor	 (the only Wind character right now), and finally  Orcane	 (the only Water character right now).

The game if fun and highly competitive. There isn't much to do but to fight locally or online, and sometimes online matches have huge input delay spikes which is a bummer but it isn't  that	 frequent.

Also, here are some youtube videos that are kinda  Radkeys.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is based of Super Smash Bros. Melee AKA Best Smash game. The available cast is small but unique with each characters having their particular mechanics and styles of play. It incorporates some of the adanved techniques found in Melee like Dash Dancing and Wavedashing (Which is made incredibly easier to perform). L-cancel isn't present as the landing lag is very low in general. The combo game is top notch making his game one that you would spend hours practicing and performing combos. Story mode and Abyss mode are not available yet and 2 characters have yet to be announced officially.

Verdict: As it stands, Rivals of Aether is a stellar and fun addition to the growing Platform Fighter genre. It is a satisfying game with the components that made Super Smash Bros. Melee such a fun game with great retention value that made the game played all the way up to this day. A great gateway game into the Smash inspired Platform Fighter genre.

Early Access Review

This game is superfun, the game has a limited cast with 6 characters right now but man the match ups are insanely fun and the art is unique.

If you like smash games this is for you,
if you like fighting games this is for you,
if you want a change of pace in mobas and CSGO this is your game
Compete with a good skill curve and great game to start!
